title: Were there any non-slave states that did, or almost, seceded from the Union and joined the Confederacy? - Quora
tags: History of the United States of America

response.answer_text: It depends on your definition of “almost” but there were some states (and parts of states) that at least talked about it, though none came that close to seceding. New Jersey, for instance, briefly considered seceding from the Union alongside the Confederacy. Former New Jersey governor Rodham Price argued quite vociferously for joining the Confederacy on the principle of economic self-interest, noting that most of New Jersey's manufactures went to the South and reasoned that, in the event of Confederate independence, New Jersey would be cut off from those markets. Note that New Jersey was the only non-slave state to vote against Lincoln in 1860. They preceeded to reject Lincoln again in 1864, one of only three states (and the only Northern state) to do so. So god bless New Jersey, I guess. That said, New Jersey did materially fall in line with the rest of the Union after Fort Sumter and provided troops and equipment for the war effort. So when push came to shove, New Jersey stayed Union. New York City similarly discussed secession. Mayor Fernando Wood actually proposed that New York form its own city-state of Tri-Insula, comprised of Brooklyn, Staten Island, and Manhattan. Again, this had a lot to do with deep New York City ties to the Southern economy and the argument that it was more reasonable for New York to maintain its very lucrative ties to Southern cotton than anything else. The proposal was turned down but New York City remained broadly skeptical of the war. Funnily enough, a secession vote (of a sort) did actually secede in the North: the tiny hamlet of Town Line, New York—in Erie County, of all places!—held a non-binding resolution to secede from the Union and join the Confederacy. Five soldiers from the town joined the Confederacy. (When a ceremonial vote to rejoin the Union was held in 1946, 23 people voted against it, but were outvoted by 90 pro-Unionists!) Ultimately, however, the Town Line vote meant precisely nothing, since the town wasn't even incorporated. That said, ideas of secession were bandied about more commonly in the early eras of the Republic. The New England states, for instance, talked relatively openly about possibly seceding from the Union during the War of 1812, since they were mostly commercial states and depended on trade with Britain. Even in the lead-up to the Civil War, certain New England agitators—like Wendell Phillips—argued that New England secede rather than associate with a country that allowed slavery to exist.
